<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Hook_GetArgPtr:
```c
const void *UT_Hook_GetArgPtr(const UT_StubContext_t *ContextPtr, const char *Name, size_t ExpectedTypeSize)
{
    uint32                      i;
    const void *                Result;
    const UT_StubArgMetaData_t *MetaPtr;

    static const union
    {
        unsigned long AsInt;
        void *        AsPtr;
        double        AsFloat;
    } ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE = {0};

    Result = NULL;
    for (i = 0; i < ContextPtr->ArgCount; ++i)
    {
        MetaPtr = &ContextPtr->Meta[i];
        if (MetaPtr->Name != NULL)
        {
            if (strcmp(MetaPtr->Name, Name) == 0 && (MetaPtr->Size == 0 || MetaPtr->Size == ExpectedTypeSize))
            {
                if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_DIRECT)
                {
                    Result = &ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                else if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_INDIRECT)
                {
                    Result = ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                break;
            }
        }
    }

    /*
     * If no suitable result pointer was found, this means a mismatch
     * between the stub and test case, such as a change in argument/parameter names.
     * This is an error that should be corrected, so report it as a failure.
     */
    if (Result == NULL)
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("Requested parameter %s of size %lu which was not provided by the stub", Name,
                        (unsigned long)ExpectedTypeSize);

        if (ExpectedTypeSize <= sizeof(ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE))
        {
            Result = &ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * As the caller will likely dereference the returned pointer, should
             * never return NULL.  Just abort here.
             */
            UtAssert_Abort("No value for parameter");
        }
    }

    return Result;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any explicit compiler language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:
- There are no GCC/Clang/other-compiler-specific keywords or builtins such as __attribute__, __asm, __volatile__ (as an extension), __builtin_*, __typeof__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as expressions, nested functions, labels-as-values (&&label), or other recognized compiler extensions.
- The static union initializer = {0} is standard C (it initializes the first member) and returning &ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE as a void pointer uses the standard implicit conversion from object pointer to void*.
- All storage-class specifiers, type specifiers and syntax used (const, static, union, for-loop, if/else, pointer assignments, function calls) conform to standard C syntax.
- The use of identifier uint32 appears to be a typedef/alias (not a language extension). Whether that typedef follows project/type-standard rules is outside Rule 1.2 (it is not a compiler language extension by itself).

Therefore there are no code fragments that need to be flagged for potential use of compiler language extensions under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
